title: Hack2theFuture Ideation Micro‑Hack
text:
Fast‑forward the future of Psychology in one micro‑hack.
    Your ideas. Your voice. Your future.

title: Hack2theFuture Ideation Micro‑Hack
text:
Overview
Today’s 3‑hour Problem‑Ideation Micro‑Hack warms you up for the real-deal Induction/Welcome‑Week hack.
We want you to frame a problem or identify a gap/need, stress‑test feasibility, identify value/feassibility, and what you might need to fix it (or start fixing it!) The ideal outcome of today is a modest seed file— a kernel of an idea to grow into a full hack project.

title: Hack2theFuture Ideation Micro‑Hack
text:
Timeline at a Glance









Minute
Activity
Purpose
Materials




0 – 5
Welcome & rules of play
Set energy, clarify “no coding yet.”
Slide deck, room mic


5 – 15
Lightning context talks (2 × 5 min)
Seed minds with domain insights.
Laptop, clicker


15 – 25
Solo brainstorm – Crazy 8s
Diverge rapidly.
A4 sheets, pens, timer


25 – 35
Affinity wall
Cluster ideas into themes.
Wall‑space, coloured sticky notes


35 – 50
Dot‑vote & Headline
Converge on top problems.
Dot stickers, Sharpies


50 – 60
Team self‑selection
Form hack teams.
Lean Problem Canvas prints


60 – 120
Lunch deep‑dive
Fill Canvas sections 1‑3 with mentors.
Food, drinks, mentors roaming


120 – 130
Round‑robin stand‑ups
Share drafts, peer feedback.
Bell/timer


130 – 150
Value × Feasibility mapping
Kill/improve risky ideas.
Flip‑chart 2‑axis grid


150 – 165
Success metrics + 1st milestone
Define “what good looks like.”
Prompt cards


165 – 175
Lightning pitches (1 slide, 1 min)
Sharpen story; commit.
Projector


175 – 180
Wrap‑up
Next steps → full hack.
Seed‑file template

Friday night of the full hack – proof‑of‑concept demo + one metric moved.

Awards: Gold Brains (Impact) · Silver Brains (Innovation) · People’s Choice (Fun)

Happy problem‑hunting—see you at the hackathon gong 🔔

title: Hack2theFuture Ideation Micro‑Hack
text:
Let’s get hacking!

Introduces and explains the purpose of the Hack page and how it will be run for the slide.
Details various “future-oriented targets”, including:

Building a future community at Goldsmiths within the psychology department.
Considering the future impact on psychologists, schools, children, and the public.
Focusing on personal future skills development and professional growth.
Exploring the future of research, including trends, innovations, and important questions.
Addressing significant questions about the future of humanity that are currently unasked.

title: Hack2theFuture Ideation Micro‑Hack
section: Plan for Induction/Welcome Week full hack
text:
Plan for Induction/Welcome Week full hack

The hack will be run as a full day event during the induction/welcome week.
Today is a seed event to get you thinking about the hack. A micro-hack if you will. The deliverables are all skeleton only, no specifics.
The key output is a ‘seed file’ that you can use to build on for the hack.
The seed file will be a markdown file with the following sections:

Title
Problem Space
Description
HackMaster volunteers
Resources needed

Experts required?
Skill ups needed?
Resources needed?

title: Hack2theFuture Ideation Micro‑Hack
text:
Future







Lens
Special emphasis




1. Local Community & Civic Life
Mental‑health equity, public engagement with Psychology or mental/physical health, wellbeing in public spaces.


2. Department & University
Departmental culture, departmental community, student voice, extracurricular activities, social scene.


3. Schools & Aspiring Psychologists
Widening participation, mentorship pathways, GCSE/A‑level alignment.


4. Personal Future (Life & Career)
Skills development, career values, finance, work–life balance, digital identity, CV and portfolio development.


5. Research & the Discipline
Reproducibility, open data norms, interdisciplinary collaboration, AI ethics.

title: Hack2theFuture Ideation Micro‑Hack
text:
Problem Canvas
┌───────────────────────────────────────┐ │ 1. FUTURE VISION (Headline) │ │ In 15–20 words, describe the │ │ desirable future you’re aiming for. │ └───────────────────────────────────────┘
┌──────────────┬────────────────────────┐ │ 2. WHO │ 3. WHERE / WHEN │ │ Who feels │ Context, setting or │ │ the pain? │ timing that triggers │ │ │ the problem. │ └──────────────┴────────────────────────┘
┌───────────────────────────────────────┐ │ 4. WHAT’S HAPPENING (Observable facts)│ │ Describe the current negative state │ │ in objective, measurable terms. │ └───────────────────────────────────────┘
┌───────────────────────────────────────┐ │ 5. WHY IT MATTERS │ │ a) Emotional impact (quotes, stories)│ │ b) Quantified cost or lost benefit │ └───────────────────────────────────────┘
┌──────────────┬────────────────────────┐ │ 6. ROOT CAUSES│ 7. EXISTING WORK‑AROUNDS│ │ Underlying │ How do people cope │ │ drivers │ today, and why does │ │ (evidence!) │ that fall short? │ └──────────────┴────────────────────────┘
┌───────────────────────────────────────┐ │ 8. STAKEHOLDERS & ROLES │ │ Who must be involved or persuaded │ │ for change to happen? │ └───────────────────────────────────────┘
┌───────────────────────────────────────┐ │ 9. SUCCESS INDICATORS (3 max) │ │ How will we know the future vision │ │ has started to materialise? │ └───────────────────────────────────────┘

title: Hack2theFuture Ideation Micro‑Hack
text:
Ideas Buffet

1 Local Community & Civic Life







Flavour
Prompt examples




Serious
“How might we cut the six‑month CBT waiting list in our NHS trust by triaging mild cases to peer‑support apps?”


Worthy
“Can we co‑design a pop‑up ‘wellbeing kiosk’ at the Goldsmiths Gate for the public passsing by?”


Fun
“Design a dog‑walking ‘buddy’ scheme pairing lonely older adults with students needing daily steps.”


Frivolous
“Map every coffee shop within a mile of campus and rank them by mood boost in a week‑long N‑of‑1 experiment.”





2 Department & University







Flavour
Prompt examples




Serious
“Mentor incoming first years in Welcome Week.”


Worthy
“Launch an Open‑Science ‘badging’ system for coursework to normalise Open Science practices in the department.”


Fun
“Develop a set of videos for first year students ‘Psycho‑Bake Off’ where cakes visualise statistical concepts.”


Frivolous
“Create a meme leaderboard that gamifies lecture attendance (and analyses the facial expressions in the memes!).”





3 Schools & Aspiring Psychologists







Flavour
Prompt examples




Serious
“Develop a compact lesson plan that gets Year 10 pupils running a mini‑experiment on sleep and grades.”


Worthy
“Mentor programme: pair undergrads with sixth‑formers from low‑participation postcodes.”


Fun
“Design a travelling ‘Brain Escape Room’ van that parks at schools during Science Week.”


Frivolous
“TikTok challenge: can teens spot the cognitive bias in trending dances?”





4 Personal Future (Life & Career)







Flavour
Prompt examples




Serious
“Build a decision‑matrix tool that matches my strengths to psychology subfields and flags required postgraduate routes.”


Worthy
“Run a month‑long ‘Money Minds’ micro‑course on budgeting & behavioural economics for students leaving halls.”


Fun
“App that finds flatmates whose chronotypes sync with mine so no one steals the bathroom at 7 a.m.”


Frivolous
“Apply self‑monitoring principles to optimise my Mario Kart lap times.”





5 Research & the Discipline







Flavour
Prompt examples




Serious
“Automate p‑curve analysis for every dissertation to flag questionable research practices.”


Worthy
“Develop a departmental ‘Repro Badge’ that only appears on posters with open data & code.”


Fun
“Curate an online museum of bizarre historical psychology experiments with modern replications.”


Frivolous
“Crowd‑source the definitive ranking of optical illusions by ‘wow’ factor.”

title: FutureSelf Panel Discussion
text:
“Come with me if you want to learn.”
  
  
  
  
  
    Co-creating the future of psychological science — one paradox at a time.

title: FutureSelf Panel Discussion
text:
1  What’s Going On?

We couldn’t afford to rent a Terminator, so we did the next best thing:
imported wisdom from your own future.
Second‑ and third‑year Psychology students will beam back lessons, hacks and tales of derring-do to help you ace the journey ahead.

Your mission, first‑years

Grill the “time‑travellers” for intel.

Capture any burning questions in the live WooClap.

Leave with at least one actionable plan for world (or degree) domination.

title: FutureSelf Panel Discussion
text:
2  Ask Your Future Self
Scan or click to open the live question box.

  


  or type: wooclap.com/OZRLIY

What to drop in the Woo

A question you don’t feel comfy asking aloud

A topic you want a deeper dive on during the Panel or afterwards

Any comments


Note: The form is anonymous. We’ll surface the most‑upvoted questions live. And any we don’t cover will be sent to the time‑travellers for a follow‑up (after exams!)

title: FutureSelf Panel Discussion
text:
3  Loot Box 🎁
Post a question for our Terminators and you’ll be entered into a prize draw for a Weird prize.

title: seats
text:
Today’s Seats Code
Sign in ONLY ONCE today - this covers 10am - 4pm

title: Hack2theFuture
text:
A day of ideas, innovation, and irreverence — brought to you by you.
This isn’t just another workshop — it’s a space to co-create tools, challenges, and hacks that make psychology more powerful, more practical, and way more fun.







GoldBrains




Visit GoldBrains →
Celebrate the best of the staff and college — the serious and the slightly weird student-voted awards. And suggest categories for student awards, maybe? If you want…






Weird Science Hack




See what’s in store →
Take control of your future in the department — ideas to make studying, socialising and researching weirder and more wonderful.






Breakout Club




Join the BreakOut →
It used to be the Breakfast Club - until we agreed we don’t like mornings. See previous examples of student-led efforts to unlock their Psychology degree with skills, puzzles, publications, portfolios and pliers.






Arnie Says




I am a cybernetic Psychologist, living tissue over metal endoskeleton →
We have teleported students from Year 2 and Year 3 to share their wisdom, hacks and tales of cunning. They will beam back insights to help you terminate the journey ahead. And you can ask them anything via WooClap here https://app.wooclap.com/OZRLIY?from=instruction-slide event code OZRLIY at wooclap.com






  
    
    
    
      
      

      
        Ghostly encounters, alien abduction, reincarnation, talking to the dead, UFO sightings, inexplicable coincidences, out-of-body and near-death experiences...
      

      
        Are these legitimate phenomena? If not, how should we understand them? In this accessible and gratifying session, 
        Chris French takes us on a tour of the paranormal — not to confirm it, but to understand why our minds so often generate it. 
        Drawing from decades of research in anomalistic psychology, he’ll walk us through scientific, statistical, and psychological explanations behind some of the most bizarre and persistent beliefs humans hold.
      

      
        Expect light-bulb moments, compelling science, and a few uncomfortable truths. This is not just a talk about ghosts and aliens — 
        it’s a masterclass in critical thinking, cognitive biases, and the psychology of belief.
      

      
        Spoiler alert: it’s not about debunking — it’s about understanding ourselves.
      
    

    
    
      
    

  




Each zone has a place for feedback and voting. Winners get glory, prizes, and questionable fame.




It’s all just R and Quarto. Follow the Github Icon in the top right and see the code.






  
    Made with ❤️,
    
    +
    
    , and questionable 80s movie references
  


  
    A LittleMonkeyLab Caper · Assembled by Dr Gordon Wright · 2025 · 
    View source 
  

  
    “I’ve seen things you people wouldn’t believe… Bonferroni ignored, assumptions untested, and interaction effects misread… saved version FINALFINALFINAL, lost - like teardrops in the rain”
  

  
    ⚠️ Warning: Exposure to this content may result in temporal disruption,vibe-coding and a mild obsession with Kenny Loggins.
